Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Design, Construction, and Validation of Modular Chassis Cells for Efficient Combinatorial Biosynthesis of Chemicals

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The envisioned rapid development of novel, biology-derived platforms for the production of industrial chemicals from renewable feedstocks requires the development of innovative new tools. The overarching goal of this project is to incorporate modular molecular design principles into microbial manufacturing platforms to enable the highly efficient synthesis of targeted chemicals from easily interchangeable genetic modules. The success of the project will advance frontiers of synthetic biology and metabolic engineering, advance biomanufacturing, train a large cohort of undergraduate and graduate students as innovators and leaders as well as expose K-12 students to STEM disciplines through hands-on experiences.

This project will address three fundamental questions: What is a modular cell? How can microbial manufacturing platforms be constructed from a minimal cell using exchangeable modules for the highly efficient combinatorial biosynthesis of novel chemicals? What classes of modules are particularly suitable to couple with the proposed modular cell? First, MOCELL computational tools will be developed to aid the design and implementation of several microbial biosynthetic platforms. Second, these MODCELL platforms will be tested after introduction of exchangeable modules that encode enzymes for specific fermentative pathways. Third, The MODCELL design will be experimentally validated for efficient combinatorial biosynthesis of targeted esters.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Transforming biology into engineering practice has a great potential to shape the industrialization of biology that will drive rapid development of novel microbial manufacturing platforms. These platforms will be capable of producing a vast number of industrially relevant chemicals at scale from alternative renewable feedstocks or wastes (e.g., biomass residues, biogas methane, syngas, CO2) without harming the environment. The challenge is to develop novel microbial manufacturing platforms to produce targeted chemicals with high efficiency in a rapid, predictable, and reproducible fashion. The conventional approach involves engineering each desirable cell in many trial-and-error optimization cycles that can take up to 5-plus years to produce a targeted chemical (e.g., 1,3-propanediol) at the industrial scale. To engineer new desirable cells to produce other target chemicals, the entire process must be repeated, which is laborious and expensive. To address the current limitation in strain engineering, the goal of the project is to develop the underlying modular design principles to engineer desirable microbial manufacturing platforms for efficient biosynthesis of targeted chemicals from biological parts in a plug-and-play fashion with minimum cell optimization efforts.

Completion of this project shed light into the fundamental questions of modular cell design: What is the modular cell? How can microbial manufacturing platforms be constructed from the modular cell and exchangeable production modules in a plug-and-play fashion for efficient combinatorial biosynthesis of novel chemicals? What classes of production modules can the modular cell couple with? This project created a blueprint of modular cells and developed MODCELL (MODULAR CELL), a computational tool, to implement the design. A modular cell is designed to be auxotrophic, containing core metabolic pathways that are necessary but insufficient to support cell growth and maintenance. To grow and produce desirable chemicals at high efficiency, the modular cell must couple with an exchangeable production module that is the auxiliary metabolic pathway to produce the targeted chemical. MODCELL was applied to design modular cells from industrially relevant organisms to produce a large library of chemicals (e.g., alcohols, acids, esters, isoprenoids, polyketides, and fatty acids.) MODCELL has been experimentally validated for rapid construction of microbial manufacturing platforms that are assembled from the modular cell and exchangeable production modules in a plug-and-play fashion for efficient biosynthesis of the targeted chemicals.

It is anticipated that the development of modular cell design principles in this project enables rapid generation of novel microbial manufacturing platforms for efficient combinatorial biosynthesis of novel chemicals in a rapid, systematic, and predictable manner. To date, this project has trained 7-plus graduate students in interdisciplinary areas of systems and synthetic biology, metabolic engineering, and computational biology. The project team has generated 21 peer-reviewed publications and several more currently in review and in preparation, and key result findings have been presented at numerous national and international conferences. The project has also integrated research and education at the departmental, intercollegiate, and K-12 levels by utilizing the supporting infrastructure at The University of Tennessee, Knoxville. At the departmental level, the PI has exposed students to new frontiers in biotechnology by incorporating the research materials into the PI’s developed courses, e.g., “Elements of Synthetic Biology and Metabolic Engineering,” and has engaged 13-plus undergraduate undergraduates to participate in the project. At the intercollegiate level, the PI has provided unique opportunities for undergraduate students to experience the excitement of research by participating in the PI-advised team in the International Genetically Engineered Machine competition. For K-12 outreach, the PI has exposed elementary-, middle- and high-school students to STEM disciplines and generate excitement with demonstrations and hands-on workshops.
